commit.message:
Update 'any' with another example and 'firmer' XOR wording. (#126)

* Update 'any' with another example and 'firmer' XOR wording.

The description of *any* as a *union* operator is easily missed, despite the presence of the word 'union': Add emphasis, more direct wording, and a clear, one-type example.

* Added missing word 'one' to 'one and only one'

commit.message: Release version 3.0.1

Use python_requires in setup.py (#112)

Current version of Yamale removed support for Python2, however trying to install it on Python2.7 results in an error. Using the python_requires keyword allows user of a specific python version to get the latest compatible package instead.

verification.payload:
tree c8b2c31a9c8a0a3e61567457c2d2b9611a90f511
parent 8fe6d02b466dd8b069200811b72c5a3a404118ca
author Hervé Audren <herve@ascent.ai> 1594654418 +0900
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1594654418 -0700

Use python_requires in setup.py (#112)

Current version of Yamale removed support for Python2, however trying to install it on Python2.7 results in an error. Using the python_requires keyword allows user of a specific python version to get the latest compatible package instead.

commit.message:
Prevent int and num validators from accepting bool values. (#109)

Adds a change to the Integer and Numeric validators such that they
won't interpret boolean values (False, True) as valid, as well as tests
outlining the expected behavior (and that 0 and 1 are still numeric).

This is an issue caused by the origin of Bool in python, as outlined in
PEP 285 -- Adding a bool type (www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0285/):
> The bool type would be a straightforward subtype (in C) of the int
> type, and the values False and True would behave like 0 and 1 in most
> respects

For historical reasons, bool is a subtype of int in Python, but that is
not the case in YAML (see e.g. https://yaml.org/type/bool.html). This
can cause issues where Yamale validates a YAML document with a bool
in an int-only field, and a downstream consumer (whether a non-python
program or a python program using .str() like e.g. jinja2) ends in an
invalid state.

The behavior of the current int and num validators can be emulated by
changing instances of 'int()' and 'num()' to 'any(int(), bool())' and
'any(num(), bool())', so there should be no loss of functionality for
users that rely on this type coercion.

verification.payload:
tree eb76d1a4efcb887343fd6c18ae3f76641671d55c
parent a9b14bdb2ef91ec0737a60ed768763ebb77e655b
author mechie <guillemmsalvador@gmail.com> 1594052473 -0400
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1594052473 -0700

Prevent int and num validators from accepting bool values. (#109)

Adds a change to the Integer and Numeric validators such that they
won't interpret boolean values (False, True) as valid, as well as tests
outlining the expected behavior (and that 0 and 1 are still numeric).

This is an issue caused by the origin of Bool in python, as outlined in
PEP 285 -- Adding a bool type (www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0285/):
> The bool type would be a straightforward subtype (in C) of the int
> type, and the values False and True would behave like 0 and 1 in most
> respects

For historical reasons, bool is a subtype of int in Python, but that is
not the case in YAML (see e.g. https://yaml.org/type/bool.html). This
can cause issues where Yamale validates a YAML document with a bool
in an int-only field, and a downstream consumer (whether a non-python
program or a python program using .str() like e.g. jinja2) ends in an
invalid state.

The behavior of the current int and num validators can be emulated by
changing instances of 'int()' and 'num()' to 'any(int(), bool())' and
'any(num(), bool())', so there should be no loss of functionality for
users that rely on this type coercion.

commit.message: Release version 2.2.0

content= argument for make_schema() and make_data() (#105)

* content= argument for make_schema() and make_data()

To allow you to pass in a string of YAML in place of a file path.

Refs https://github.com/23andMe/Yamale/issues/104

* Test for parse_yaml() TypeError on bad arguments

Refs https://github.com/23andMe/Yamale/issues/104

* Better error messages for schema/data

* Removed unnecessary comment

* Add \n\t after error message header

committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1593190717 -0700

commit.message: Remove graphic
Release version 2.1.0

Construct Result object for schema errors (#101)

The schema errors were short-circuiting the rest of the yaml validation
when processing several directories. Wrapping them in a Result object
and passing it along as we do with yaml validation results lets all
these results be processed at the end.

verification.payload:
tree 0ed66bd3739194e70dcba7adefa45369011395a8
parent 21926d6cd53a68eac461e7c15e61757ee8d46838
author Chris Mildebrandt <chrism@23andme.com> 1591130672 -0700
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1591130672 -0700

Construct Result object for schema errors (#101)

The schema errors were short-circuiting the rest of the yaml validation
when processing several directories. Wrapping them in a Result object
and passing it along as we do with yaml validation results lets all
these results be processed at the end.

commit.message:
Add support to the "map" validator for constraining the keys (#95)

* Add support for a "key" constraint to the "map" validator

This constraint allows a validator to be applied to the keys of the map, in
addition to the usual validator applied to the values

* Add some tests of the new "key" constraint on "map"

These tests cover the case of a map at the base level, as well as a map in a
nested list. There are much more complicated cases that could, and perhaps
ought, to be tested though...

* Minor cosmetic fix

* Update documentation of "Map" to describe the "key" constraint

* Add keywords to the documented "List" prototype

* Remove unusual extra line breaks

Utterly minor thing, but the document is otherwise bereft of double blank lines
so if there is a consistent "style" then that style is to only use one blank
line to separate sections.

verification.payload:
tree 10ddc679f4b7d2ae0f530cc24dc6edfe4415c295
parent d2488938ad022201f60e8da0f0e7d57e3d11a76d
author Violet <phidica.veia@gmail.com> 1588007730 +0000
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1588007730 -0700

Add support to the "map" validator for constraining the keys (#95)

This constraint allows a validator to be applied to the keys of the map, in
addition to the usual validator applied to the values

* Add some tests of the new "key" constraint on "map"

These tests cover the case of a map at the base level, as well as a map in a

ought, to be tested though...

* Update documentation of "Map" to describe the "key" constraint

Utterly minor thing, but the document is otherwise bereft of double blank lines
so if there is a consistent "style" then that style is to only use one blank
line to separate sections.
